title: U.S. Job Gains Bolster Case for Raising Interest Rates; How Fed's Plans for Balance Sheet May Temper Rate Increases
text:
Top News

A steady gain in hiring last month keeps the Federal Reserve on track to lift interest rates next month and could prompt increases at meetings in May and June.

Fed officials had already signaled they were prepared to look past Friday's report amid fears of a hiring slowdown from the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, which surged across the U.S. last month. Instead, the report showed surprising strength in hiring, not just last month, but over the past several months.

Powell Designated Fed ‘Chair Pro Tempore'

The Federal Reserve's board of governors voted to designate Jerome Powell as its leader once his four-year term expired on Saturday, pending Senate confirmation, a move that has occurred only three other times in the Fed's history.

Derby's Take: How Fed Approaches Balance Sheet Could Affect Rate Increase Path

By Michael S. Derby

Speaking last week, Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City leader Esther George joined with a range of her colleagues and agreed that with inflation running too high, the Fed needs to dial back on stimulus to help bring price pressures back down toward the central bank's 2% target.

Ms. George also explained that the interplay of rate rises and the Fed's nearly $9 trillion balance sheet are linked. If the Fed allows an aggressive run off in the balance sheet, that might allow it to raise rates less aggressively over time, she said. Read more.

U.S. Economy

U.S. Readies New Asia-Pacific Economic Strategy to Counter China

The Biden administration is preparing to unveil its first broad economic strategy for the Asia-Pacific region, a move awaited by U.S. allies and American business groups that are uneasy about China's expanding influence in the region.

House Approves $350 Billion ‘America Competes Act'

The House approved a $350 billion plan Friday to boost U.S. competitiveness with China and other rivals, but differences with the Senate and partisan divides signaled struggles ahead in reaching a compromise. The Senate in June passed its $250 billion version of the measure.

Jobs Growth Surged in January as Economy Weathered Omicron

U.S. employers hired workers at a swift pace in January after bulking up more than previously reported at the end of last year, reflecting the economy is growing solidly in the face of the Omicron wave of Covid-19 and staffing shortages. The U.S. economy added 467,000 jobs in January, the Labor Department said, and job growth was about 700,000 higher in November and December combined than previously reported.

Worker Absences From Covid-19 Hold Back Companies' Growth

Employers from McDonald's Corp. to home builder PulteGroup Inc. said staffing pressures caused by hiring challenges and surging Covid-19 cases suppressed growth or cut into operations in the fourth quarter.

Food Companies Rely More on Temp Workers Amid Labor Shortages

An American Labor Market Mystery

Between the fourth quarters of 2019 and 2021, the labor-force participation rate—the share of the population ages 15 to 64 either working or looking for work—dropped 0.7 percentage point in the U.S., while rising in Japan and Canada.

Key Developments Around the World

China's Slowdown to Limit Global Growth

A prolonged slowdown in China's economic growth could hurt some multinational companies and commodity producers for years to come, casting a shadow over the global recovery from the pandemic—but likely not derailing it entirely.

Russian Record in Occupied Eastern Ukraine Serves as Warning

Developments in Donetsk and Luhansk show what many fear could happen to the rest of Ukraine, and a dismal record of Russian rule there is one reason so many Ukrainian citizens are ready to take up arms so their hometowns won't meet the same fate.

Financial Regulation Roundup

Biden's Regulatory Drive Sparks Pushback From Business Lobbyists

The White House's newly installed chiefs at regulatory agencies are rolling out a lengthy list of new rules, with financial-services regulators advancing measures to address climate change and workplace diversity and crack down on Wall Street profiteering.

On TV in China, Corrupt Officials, Corporate Villains Are Bad Guys

"Zero Tolerance," a documentary series aired on national television and streaming sites in January, lined up fallen Communist Party members who walked the audience through their own allegedly sinful pasts—tales of bribery and other corrupt dealings with companies.

Forward Guidance

Monday (all times ET)

10:45 a.m.: ECB's Lagarde speaks at hearing before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs

Tuesday

Time N/A: National Bank of Poland releases policy statement

8:30 a.m.: U.S. International trade in goods and services report for December 2021

Commentary

Europe's Hawkish Pivot Could Be More Bark Than Bite

European central banks seem ready to join the Fed on a cycle of tighter monetary policy, but their actions may have more to do with the misguided attempt to throw "shock and awe" at inflation expectations than a true commitment to higher interest rates, Jon Sindreu writes.

Omicron Was No Match for the Job Market

The January job gain is especially striking given that the midmonth pay period the Labor Department based its employment figures on came precisely when the Omicron-fueled surge in Covid-19 cases was at its worst, Justin Lahart writes.

Basis Points

The world's biggest shipping lines, flush with cash, are buying their own fleets of cargo planes and adding airlifts for big clients willing to pay extra to get around supply-chain snarls at sea resulting from the Covid-19 pandemic.

President Biden signed an executive order on Friday mandating that the U.S. government enter into agreements with labor unions setting pay and conditions for federal construction projects that cost more than $35 million.

The Biden administration will extend a set of tariffs on solar-energy imports for four years, but significantly reduce their scope by doubling the amount of solar cells that can enter the U.S. without facing any levies.

Mexico's car and light car output fell in January by 9.1% from a year earlier, statistics institute Inegi said, adding that exports fell 3.1% from a year earlier. Worker absences due to the Omicron variant and the continued shortage of semiconductors weighed on the industry at the start of the year, according to auto industry association AMIA. (Dow Jones Newswires)

Australian retail volumes jumped by a record 8.2% in 4Q, bouncing back from a record 3.4% decline in 3Q. The data indicates underlying demand in the economy remains robust despite Omicron, and a fast start to 2022 is likely. (DJN)

China's foreign-exchange reserves dropped by $28.5 billion to $3.222 trillion in January, due to a decline in global asset prices, the People's Bank of China said. The result ended a streak of three consecutive monthly increases in reserves. A poll of economists by The Wall Street Journal had expected the country's forex reserves at $3.250 trillion, unchanged from the end of December. (DJN)

China's services sector slipped to a five-month low at the beginning of the year, as Covid-19 flare-ups and strict restrictions disrupted consumer spending. The Caixin China services purchasing managers index dropped to 51.4 in January from 53.1 in December, Caixin Media Co. and research company IHS Markit said. Still, the reading remained above the 50 mark, which separates month-to-month activity expansion from contraction. (DJN)

Chinese Lunar New Year travel rose 45% from a year earlier, which may have boosted consumption in small cities as people returned to their hometowns for the holiday, CICC says. Smaller Chinese cities reported better box-office revenue than large cities over the holiday, CICC notes. But the number of travelers remained 65% lower than the pre-pandemic level recorded in 2019. (DJN)

Eurozone retail sales fell in December due to a rise in Covid-19 cases across Europe with the spread of the Omicron variant, Eurostat said, reporting the month's volume of retail sales declined 3.0% on month after a 1.0% rise in November. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had forecast a 0.5% decline for December. (DJN)

German industrial production fell in December after increasing the previous month as energy and construction acted as a drag on overall output. Total industrial output--comprising production in manufacturing, energy and construction--fell 0.3% in December compared with the previous month in calendar-adjusted terms, statistics office Destatis said. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had forecast a 0.4% increase. (DJN)
